titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Walter Schuetrum Papers ALBA.136
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ariel Zambenedetti, 2008. Entered into Archivists Toolkit by Kate Dundon

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-03-28T16:46-0400

did.langmaterial: Materials are in English, Spanish, German, Swedish, French, and Catalan
did.abstract: Walter Schuetrum was an Ambulance Driver in the Spanish Civil War. This collection of his papers includes materials from his time spent in Spain, as well as correspondence and papers from the 1960s-1980s.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Walter Schuetrum Papers were donated to the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives by Nancy Fontana, in 1996. This collection came to New York University in January 2001 as part of the original acquisition of ALBA collections, formerly housed at Brandeis University.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Photographs from the Walter Schuetrum Papers have been transferred to the non-print section of the ALBA collection in the Tamiment Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
relatedmaterial.p: ALBA collections at the Tamiment Library.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Walter Schuetrum was born in Superior, Wisconsin on October 18, 1911. The son of a miner turned switchman for the Great Northern Railroad, Schuetrum was instilled early on in his life with a concern for political and labor issues, and in 1937 he volunteered for the Loyalist forces in Spain. There he served as an Ambulance driver, and was present at many of the War’s crucial battles. In the aftermath of the Battle of Teruel he was reported deceased, misinformation that was spread in Wisconsin Newspapers at the time and only righted after he wrote a letter to his family to dispel these rumors.

After the Spanish Civil War, Schuetrum returned to Wisconsin and soon after moved with his wife to San Francisco. On the West Coast, he got a job as a Longshoreman and became an active member and organizer for the I.L.W.U. During World War II, Schuetrum joined the army, but due to his involvement in the Spanish Civil War, was barred from fighting over seas and instead worked as an instructor on land ships at the Indiantown Gap military Reservation in Pennsylvania. He was discharged in 1946.

In 1961, Schuetrum, along with other IB veterans, was invited to the G.D.R. and spent three months there. Along with other Vets who attended that trip (Including Sana Goldblatt and Steve Troxell), Schuetrum later helped establish the Bay Area Post of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. Although he never held an Administrative position with VALB, he was nonetheless directly involved in many of its activities and proceedings.
Sources: Fontana, Nancy. “Walter Schuetrum, My Father”. The Volunteer Vol. III, 2 (Oct. 1986)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: The collection is separated into three series.

Series I. Spanish Civil War Files, 1937-1939 consists of material from 1937-1939, from Schuetrum’s time in Spain and immediately following. Included are letters from him to his family and friends, documents pertaining to his membership in the IB and various other Spanish organizations, and ephemera collected during his tour.

Series II. General Files, 1946-1987 consists of all materials that postdate the Spanish Civil War. Included are documents pertaining to Schuetrum’s enlistment in the Army, his membership in the I.L.W.U, and correspondence from friends and other veterans. Much of the material dated after 1970 is V.A.L.B. related.
Series III. Artifacts and Memorabilia consists of non-print memorabilia from Spain.
